bestBHT.bht: Some individuals who heard the word of God had hearts that were like thorny ground; when the word was preached to them, it did not take root. These people made a quick and superficial profession of faith without truly experiencing the transformative power of the word. If their hearts had been deeper, the word would have had more time to do its work and they would have had a more substantial and genuine profession of faith.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: What means this? See on Matthew 13:5- :."
John Gill: The word was preached to some persons who had hearts of stone, and which remained so.
A sudden and hasty profession of the word was made, without a powerful experience of it.
If it had [depth of earth], it would have been longer in coming up; more work would have been done by it, which would have required more time, before a profession of it had been made.

bhtAttempts.bht: Some individuals who heard the word of God had hearts that were like thorny ground; when the word was preached to them, it did not take root. These people made a quick and superficial profession of faith without truly experiencing the transformative power of the word. If their hearts had been deeper, the word would have had more time to do its work and they would have had a more substantial and genuine profession of faith.

Some people heard the word of God but had hearts like thorny ground, choked by the cares of the world and the deceitfulness of riches. Their response to the word was hasty and shallow, lacking a true transformation of heart. If their hearts had been deeper, rooted in the word, the growth would have been slower but more substantial, and a genuine profession of faith would have been made. (Matthew 13:5-; Mark 4:7; Mark 4:18; Mark 4:19)

Some individuals heard the word of God, but their response was shallow and lacking a true transformation. Their hearts resembled thorny ground that was choked by worldly concerns and the allure of material wealth. Their response was hasty, without a deep understanding or experience of the word. If their hearts had been rooted deeply in the word, the growth would have been slower but more substantial, leading to a genuine profession of faith.

Upon hearing the word of God, some people responded without experiencing its power, their hearts remaining hard like stone. Their profession of faith was sudden and lacking depth, as they failed to truly understand and internalize the message. If their hearts had been more receptive, the growth of their faith would have been more deliberate and profound, requiring time and genuine work. (Matthew 13:5-; Mark 4:7; Mark 4:18; Mark 4:19)

In response to the preaching of the word, there were those whose hearts resembled thorny ground, hindered by worldly distractions and the deceitfulness of riches. Their profession of faith was quick and superficial, lacking a genuine experience of its power. If their hearts had been more receptive and grounded, the growth would have been gradual, allowing for a deeper transformation to take place before making a sincere profession of faith.
